title: If I am in Yellowstone when the Caldera erupts, what happens to me? - Quora

response.answer_text: Answered 29 August, 2020 When Yellowstone erupts again and you’re in the caldera nothing happens to you, unless you’re extremely unlucky to be standing exactly where a phreatic explosion happens. That’s because you’re probably unaware of the small event predicted as the next one to occur, the caldera is that large. The question presumes that every eruption of the Yellowstone hot spot is a super eruption. 80 of the 81 most recent eruptions have been lava flows, steam/hydrothermal explosions, gas emissions or single vent volcanoes of less than Category:VEI-8. Now, a VEI 7 event, one the size of which made the Valles Caldera in New Mexico or destroyed Santorini near Greece would be very destructive to anybody in the park. The good news is that, decades before that can happen, before much of the crystalised mush beneath the caldera could melt in order to made a large-scale eruption possible there would be a specialised sort of earthquake called “magmatic” creating harmonic tremours. Yellowstone’s hot spot can’t erupt in a caldera-forming eruption with no warning as portrayed in Hollywood, the BBC or the Daily Express. The only people in harms way of such an event would be scientists studying it or scofflaws in the backcountry who snuck in after the evacuation order. Jesse Lee O’Connor 李杰西's answer to If the Yellowstone super volcano were to break open, how much warning might we expect?  What would happen if the Yellowstone supervolcano actually erupted? The next predicted eruption being hydrothermal/phreatic would not be noticed by people more than a few kilometres away. A gas release such as killed five bison in 2004 may not be noticed till the next spring. What type of eruption will Yellowstone have if it erupts again? And, to be precise, a caldera cannot erupt. It’s the remnant of a past large-scale eruption. Magma chambers may erupt when conditions are right, which they aren’t at this time and would take years if ever again to develop so at this location. Geophysicist: Calling Yellowstone a 'supervolcano' is trite, misleading - Casper, WY Oil City News

Actually, according to USGS, some 68% of the eruptions are effusive, (flowing magma - lava). So, depending on you location in the park, (It’s a huge park covering some 3400 square miles), you could see the erupting lava flow from a safe distances. But even if you in the actual caldera, there are going to be warning signs that an eruption is imminent. Also, the park service has emergency sirens in the park to warn visitors to evacuate immediately. But, if you are unfortunate enough to be ANYWHERE in the park when an ‘explosive eruption’ occurs - well then you’re toast. Those really big events happen about every 600 to 800 thousand years apart.
